kpis.description: Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) is a prediction of the net profit attributed to the entire future relationship with a customer. It helps businesses understand how much they can spend to acquire customers while still maintaining profitability.
kpis.formula: CLV = Average Purchase Value x Average Purchase Frequency x Customer Lifespan

kpis.description: The Customer Lifetime Index (CLI) is a metric that quantifies the value of a customer over their entire relationship with a business, often expressed as a score that reflects their loyalty and potential future purchases.
kpis.formula: CLI = Average Customer Lifespan x Average Revenue per User (ARPU)

kpis.description: Retention Rate is the percentage of customers who continue to do business with a company over a specific period. It is a key indicator of customer satisfaction and loyalty.
values_need_in_formula: Number of Customers at End of Period
Number of New Customers Acquired During Period
kpis.formula: Retention Rate = (Number of Customers at End of Period - Number of New Customers Acquired) / Number of Customers at Start of Period x 100

kpis.description: Churn Rate is the percentage of customers who stop doing business with a company during a given time frame. It is a critical metric for understanding customer attrition and the effectiveness of retention strategies.
values_need_in_formula: Number of Customers Lost During Period
Number of Customers at Start of Period
kpis.formula: Churn Rate = Number of Customers Lost / Number of Customers at Start of Period x 100

kpis.description: The CLV to CAC ratio compares the Customer Lifetime Value to the Customer Acquisition Cost. A higher ratio indicates that the value generated from a customer is significantly greater than the cost of acquiring them, which is a sign of a healthy business model.
kpis.formula: CLV to CAC Ratio = CLV / CAC
